question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
At a school, all 60 students play on at least one of three teams: Basketball, Soccer, and Mathletics. 8 students play all three sports, half the students play basketball, and the ratio of the size of the math team to the size of the basketball team to the size of the soccer team is $4:3:2$. How many students at the school play on exactly two teams?
inference:
Let $B$ be the set of students who play basketball, $S$ be the set of students who play soccer, and $M$ be the set of students who play mathletics.
We are given that $|B \cup S \cup M| = 60$.
$|B \cap S \cap M| = 8$.
$|B| = 30$.
$|M| : |B| : |S| = 4 : 3 : 2$.
$|M| = \frac{4}{3} |B| = \frac{4}{3} \times 30 = 40$.
$|S| = \frac{2}{3} |B| = \frac{2}{3} \times 30 = 20$.
By the Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion,
$|B \cup S \cup M| = |B| + |S| + |M| - |B \cap S| - |B \cap M| - |S \cap M| + |B \cap S \cap M|$.
$60 = 30 + 20 + 40 - |B \cap S| - |B \cap M| - |S \cap M| + 8$.
$60 = 90 - |B \cap S| - |B \cap M| - |S \cap M| + 8$.
$60 = 98 - |B \cap S| - |B \cap M| - |S \cap M|$.
$|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M| = 98 - 60 = 38$.
Let $x = |B \cap S|$, $y = |B \cap M|$, $z = |S \cap M|$.
$x + y + z = 38$.
$|B \cap S| - |B \cap S \cap M| = x - 8$.
$|B \cap M| - |B \cap S \cap M| = y - 8$.
$|S \cap M| - |B \cap S \cap M| = z - 8$.
$x + y + z = 38$.
Also $x + y + z - 3(8) = 38 - 24 = 14$.
The number of students who play exactly two teams is $x + y + z - 3 \times |B \cap S \cap M|$.
The number of students playing exactly two teams is $14$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{14}$
ground_truth: We have enough information to solve for the size of each team. There are $\dfrac{60}{2}=30$ members of the basketball team, $\dfrac{4}{3}(30)=40$ members of the math team, and $\dfrac{2}{3}(30)=20$ members of the soccer team. Adding these up gives us 90, so clearly we're overcounting since there are only 60 students. The number of times that each student is counted in this total is equal to the number of teams that student plays on. This means that all 60 students will be counted at least once, all students who play exactly two sports will be counted one extra time, and all students who play three sports will be counted two extra times. Letting $x$ be the number of students who play two sports and $y$ be the number who play all three gives us $60+x+2y=90$. However, we know that $y=8$, so we can substitute that in and get $x=\boxed{14}$.

question:
Let $B$ be the set of students who play basketball, $S$ be the set of students who play soccer, and $M$ be the set of students who play mathletics.
We are given that $|B \cup S \cup M| = 60$.
$|B \cap S \cap M| = 8$.
$|B| = 30$.
$|M| : |B| : |S| = 4 : 3 : 2$.
$|M| = \frac{4}{3} |B| = \frac{4}{3} \times 30 = 40$.
$|S| = \frac{2}{3} |B| = \frac{2}{3} \times 30 = 20$.
By the Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion,
$|B \cup S \cup M| = |B| + |S| + |M| - |B \cap S| - |B \cap M| - |S \cap M| + |B \cap S \cap M|$.
$60 = 30 + 20 + 40 - |B \cap S| - |B \cap M| - |S \cap M| + 8$.
$60 = 90 - |B \cap S| - |B \cap M| - |S \cap M| + 8$.
$60 = 98 - |B \cap S| - |B \cap M| - |S \cap M|$.
$|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M| = 98 - 60 = 38$.
Let $x = |B \cap S|$, $y = |B \cap M|$, $z = |S \cap M|$.
$x + y + z = 38$.
$|B \cap S| - |B \cap S \cap M| = x - 8$.
$|B \cap M| - |B \cap S \cap M| = y - 8$.
$|S \cap M| - |B \cap S \cap M| = z - 8$.
$x + y + z = 38$.
Also $x + y + z - 3(8) = 38 - 24 = 14$.
The number of students who play exactly two teams is $x + y + z - 3 \times |B \cap S \cap M|$.
The number of students playing exactly two teams is $14$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{14}$

inference:
$|B \cup S \cup M| = |B| + |S| + |M| - (|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M|) + |B \cap S \cap M|$
$60 = 30 + 20 + 40 - (|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M|) + 8$
$60 = 90 - (|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M|) + 8$
$|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M| = 90 - 60 - 8 = 22$
Let $x = |B \cap S|$, $y = |B \cap M|$, $z = |S \cap M|$. Then $x+y+z = 22$.
The number of students who play exactly two sports is
$|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M| - 3 |B \cap S \cap M| = x+y+z-3(8) = 22 - 24 = -2$.
Since the number of students playing exactly two sports cannot be negative, there must be a mistake in the calculation.


The number of students who play exactly two sports is
$(|B \cap S| - |B \cap S \cap M|) + (|B \cap M| - |B \cap S \cap M|) + (|S \cap M| - |B \cap S \cap M|) = (|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M|) - 3|B \cap S \cap M|$
$= 22 - 3(8) = 22 - 24 = -2$.

The number of students who play exactly two sports is $(x - 8) + (y - 8) + (z - 8)$.
Since $x+y+z = 22$, the number of students who play exactly two sports is $(x+y+z) - 3(8) = 22 - 24 = -2$.  This is impossible.


$|B \cup S \cup M| = |B| + |S| + |M| - (|B \cap S| + |B \cap M| + |S \cap M|) + |B \cap S \cap M|$
$60 = 30 + 20 + 40 - (x+y+z) + 8$
$60 = 90 - (x+y+z) + 8$
$60 = 98 - (x+y+z)$
$x+y+z = 98-60 = 38$


The number of students who play exactly two sports is
$(|B \cap S| - |B \cap S \cap M|) + (|B \cap M| - |B \cap S \cap M|) + (|S \cap M| - |B \cap S \cap M|) = (x+y+z) - 3(8) = 38 - 24 = 14$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{14}$
ground_truth: We have enough information to solve for the size of each team. There are $\dfrac{60}{2}=30$ members of the basketball team, $\dfrac{4}{3}(30)=40$ members of the math team, and $\dfrac{2}{3}(30)=20$ members of the soccer team. Adding these up gives us 90, so clearly we're overcounting since there are only 60 students. The number of times that each student is counted in this total is equal to the number of teams that student plays on. This means that all 60 students will be counted at least once, all students who play exactly two sports will be counted one extra time, and all students who play three sports will be counted two extra times. Letting $x$ be the number of students who play two sports and $y$ be the number who play all three gives us $60+x+2y=90$. However, we know that $y=8$, so we can substitute that in and get $x=\boxed{14}$.
